0.title: Do schools kill creativity?
0.speaker: Sir Ken Robinson
0.description: Sir Ken Robinson makes an entertaining and profoundly moving case for creating an education system that nurtures (rather than undermines) creativity.
0.transcript:
Good morning. How are you?(Audience) Good.It's been great, hasn't it?(Laughter)There have been three themes
running through the conference,I have an interest in education.(Laughter)If you work in education,
you're not asked.(Laughter)And you're never asked back, curiously.
That's strange to me.(Laughter)"My one night out all week."(Laughter)But if you ask about their education,
they pin you to the wall,And the third part of this
is that we've all agreed, nonetheless,So I want to talk about education,(Applause)Thank you.(Applause)That was it, by the way.
Thank you very much.(Laughter)So, 15 minutes left.(Laughter)"Well, I was born ... "(Laughter)I heard a great story recently --
I love telling it --(Laughter)When my son was four in England --(Laughter)If we're being strict about it,
wherever he went, he was four that year.(Laughter)No, it was big, it was a big story.(Laughter)"Nativity II."(Laughter)What these things have in common
is that kids will take a chance.Picasso once said this, he said
that all children are born artists.I lived in Stratford-on-Avon
until about five years ago.(Laughter)Actually, we lived in a place
called Snitterfield,(Laughter)How annoying would that be?(Laughter)"Must try harder."(Laughter)Being sent to bed by his dad,
to Shakespeare, "Go to bed, now!"(Laughter)"And stop speaking like that."(Laughter)"It's confusing everybody."(Laughter)Anyway, we moved
from Stratford to Los Angeles,(Laughter)Mind you, they'd had
their fourth anniversary,(Laughter)because she was the main reason
we were leaving the country.(Laughter)But something strikes you
when you move to America(Laughter)Truthfully, what happens is,
as children grow up,If you were to visit education as an alien(Laughter)And I like university professors,(Laughter)Don't they?(Laughter)If you want real evidence
of out-of-body experiences, by the way,(Laughter)And there, you will see it.(Laughter)Waiting until it ends, so they can
go home and write a paper about it.(Laughter)Our education system is predicated
on the idea of academic ability.Number one, that the most useful
subjects for work are at the top.And the second is academic ability,In the next 30 years, according to UNESCO,Suddenly, degrees aren't worth anything.(Laughter)But now kids with degrees
are often heading homeWe know three things about intelligence.By the way, there's a shaft of nerves
that joins the two halves of the brain,(Laughter)No, she's good at some things.(Laughter)she's doing open-heart surgery over here.(Laughter)"Give me a break."(Laughter)Actually, do you know
that old philosophical thing,(Laughter)And the third thing about intelligence is,(Laughter)Gillian and I had lunch one day.
I said, "How did you get to be a dancer?"(Laughter)People weren't aware they could have that.(Laughter)Anyway, she went to see this specialist.But as they went out of the room,I said, "What happened?"(Applause)What I think it comes to is this:There was a wonderful quote
by Jonas Salk, who said,What TED celebrates is the gift
of the human imagination.Thank you very much.(Applause)

1.title: Greening the ghetto
1.speaker: Majora Carter
1.description: In an emotionally charged talk, MacArthur-winning activist Majora Carter details her fight for environmental justice in the South Bronx -- and shows how minority neighborhoods suffer most from flawed urban policy.
1.transcript:
If you're here today --The reason why I'm here today,
in part, is because of a dog --So when I was contacted
by the Parks DepartmentAnd just like my new dog, it was an idea
that got bigger than I'd imagined.And in the fall, I'm going to exchange
marriage vows with my beloved.(Audience whistles)Thank you very much.(Applause)That's him pressing my buttons
back there, which he does all the time.(Laughter)(Applause)But those of us living
in environmental justice communitiesUnfortunately, race and class
are extremely reliable indicatorsFortunately, there are many people
like me who are striving for solutionsWell, first of all,
we're all incredibly good-looking.(Laughter)Graduated high school, college,
post-graduate degrees,(Laughter)But, besides being a black woman,So how did things get so different for us?Hunts Point was formerly
a walk-to-work community,Now, why is this story important?Once we realized that, we decided
it was time to do our own planning.As we nurture the natural environment,
its abundance will give us back even more.We also built New York City's first green
and cool roof demonstration project[Butterfly](Laughter)So cool!Anyway, the demonstration
project is a springboard[Green is the new black ...](Laughter) (Applause)I like that, too.Anyway, I know Chris told us
not to do pitches up here,(Laughter)(Applause)OK. Katrina.Prior to Katrina, the South Bronx
and New Orleans' Ninth WardNow listen, I do not expect individuals,(Laughter)But -- I know it's the bottom line,
or one's perception of it,At present, that's not happening
in New York City.Now let's get this straight:
I am not anti-development.(Laughter)You probably all have,
and if you haven't, you need to.(Laughter)So I don't have a problem
with developers making money.Let's take Bogota.You, however, are blessed
with the gift of influence.Listen -- when I spoke to Mr. Gore
the other day after breakfast,(Applause)What troubled me was that this
top-down approach is still around.(Laughter)But grassroots groups
are needed at the table(Applause)I have come from so far
to meet you like this.Ciao, bellos!(Applause)

2.title: Simplicity sells
2.speaker: David Pogue
2.description: New York Times columnist David Pogue takes aim at technology’s worst interface-design offenders, and provides encouraging examples of products that get it right. To funny things up, he bursts into song.
2.transcript:
(Music: "The Sound of Silence,"
Simon & Garfunkel)Hello voice mail, my old friend.(Laughter)I've called for tech support again.(Laughter)And you listen to the sounds of silence.(Music)(Applause)Thank you.Good evening and welcome to:(Laughter)When I was offered the Times
column six years ago,If you ever are feeling lonely,(Laughter)Ok, so why is the problem accelerating?(Laughter)So the irony is, that as these
things became easier to use,I once had the distinct privilege
of sitting in on the Apple call center(Laughter)Which they do.(Laughter)And I have a copy.(Laughter)It's in your gift bag. No, no.So, some of the stories are just
so classic, and yet so understandable."Well, ma'am, what do you mean
your mouse is squeaking?"She says, "All I can tell you
is that it squeaks louder,(Laughter)And the technician's like,She goes, "Well, the message said,
'Click here to continue.'"(Laughter)Well, if you like that one --
how much time have we got?(Laughter)So, we must admitIn the hardware world, it's because
we the consumers wantI mean, Microsoft Word was last
just a word processor in, you know,(Laughter)But what's the alternative?(Laughter)This is an un-retouched --
this is not a joke --(Laughter)And we've arrived at the age
of interface matrices,Here's Apple's take
on the exact same dialogue box.(Applause)Thank you -- yes, I designed
the dialogue box. No, no.[Welcome to the Type a Word Wizard](Laughter)(Applause)"Welcome to the Type a Word Wizard."(Laughter)(Applause)From the drop-down menu, choose
the first letter you want to type. Ok.(Laughter)So there is a limit
that we don't want to cross.If you are buying something on the web,(Laughter)You have to scroll, like,
seven screensful to get to it.This one's been touched on before,(Laughter)Here's another pet one of mine:
you have a printer.(Laughter)And one of the buttons at the bottom,
you'll notice, is not "Print."(Laughter)(Applause)Now, I'm not saying that Apple
is the only company who has embraced(Laughter)This is Microsoft Word.(Laughter)You go up to the "File" menu
and you choose "New."(Laughter)(Applause)The Bill Gates song!(Piano music)I've been a geek forever(Laughter)I write the code
that makes the whole world run.(Applause)But actually, I believe
there are really two Microsofts.(Laughter)So, the signs might indicate(Laughter)with Madonna,(Music)It won't be easy.
You'll think I'm strange.(Laughter)When I try to explain why I'm back,(Laughter)You try rhyming with garage!(Laughter)Don't cry for me, Cupertino.(Laughter)The truth is, I never left you.(Laughter)Don't cry for me, Cupertino.(Laughter)(Applause)Thank you.So Steve Jobs had always believed
in simplicity and elegance and beauty.(Laughter)But it turns out I was wrong, right?I've got just a couple examples.Chris Anderson: Oh yeah.
DP: Hold that and don't let go.(Applause)In my very last example --[Thank you so much
for taking the time to write ...](Laughter)(Applause)And conversely, if somebody
sends me hate mail --(Laughter)[I admire your frankness ...](Laughter)(Applause)So that's my dirty little secret.
Don't tell anyone.(Laughter)So the point is --
this is a really interesting story.This cult of doing things right
is starting to spread.CA: Bravo. DP: Thank you very much.CA: Hear, hear!(Applause)

3.title: Averting the climate crisis
3.speaker: Al Gore
3.description: With the same humor and humanity he exuded in "An Inconvenient Truth," Al Gore spells out 15 ways that individuals can address climate change immediately, from buying a hybrid to inventing a new, hotter brand name for global warming.
3.transcript:
Thank you so much, Chris.(Laughter)Put yourselves in my position.(Laughter)I flew on Air Force Two for eight years.(Laughter)Now I have to take off my shoes
or boots to get on an airplane!(Laughter)(Applause)I'll tell you one quick story(Laughter)It's a true story --
every bit of this is true.Soon after Tipper and I left the --
(Mock sob) White House --(Laughter)we were driving from our home
in Nashville to a little farm we have(Laughter)I know it sounds like
a little thing to you, but --(Laughter)I looked in the rear-view mirror(Laughter)You've heard of phantom limb pain?(Laughter)This was a rented Ford Taurus.(Laughter)It was dinnertime,(Laughter)She took our order, and then went
to the couple in the booth next to us,(Laughter)(Applause)There's been kind
of a series of epiphanies.(Laughter)The very next day,
continuing the totally true story,(Laughter)But what it turned out to be,(Laughter)And the story began,(Laughter)"'named Shoney's,(Laughter)Before I could get back to U.S. soil,(Laughter)Three days later,(Laughter)We like to celebrate
each other's successes in life.(Laughter)I was going to talk
about information ecology.(Applause)Chris Anderson: It's a deal!(Applause)Al Gore: I want to focus
on what many of you have saidNow, I know that you wanted some more
bad news about the environment --Cars and trucks -- I talked
about that in the slideshow,Reduce emissions in your home.Be a green consumer.There is a carbon calculator.Next, consider making
your business carbon-neutral.Become a catalyst of change.(Applause)Where did anybody get the ideaAnd in our modern country, the role
of logic and reason no longer includes(Laughter)That's really true.I said the other night,
and I'll repeat now:Thank you very much, I appreciate it.(Applause)

4.title: The best stats you've ever seen
4.speaker: Hans Rosling
4.description: You've never seen data presented like this. With the drama and urgency of a sportscaster, statistics guru Hans Rosling debunks myths about the so-called "developing world."
4.transcript:
About 10 years ago, I took on the task
to teach global developmentAnd I put them together
so that in each pair of countries,(Laughter)But one late night,
when I was compiling the report,(Laughter)Because the chimpanzee
would score half rightI did also an unethical study(Laughter)This is where I realized that
there was really a need to communicate,So we did this software,
which displays it like this.(Laughter)And they said, "The world
is still 'we' and 'them.'So this is what I could display here.Let's see. We stopped the world then.In the '80s here, you have Bangladesh
still among the African countries.(Applause)(Applause ends)Let me make a comparison directlySo let's move over to another way hereWe heard it in other forms.And what did it look like
if we go back in time,Of course it's a logarithmic scale here,But let me split sub-Saharan Africa.There's a huge difference [within] Africa.Data is often better than you think.
Many people say data is bad.And we get the whole pattern
here of the world,But I would like to bring you back
to about here, at 1960.And if we move back again, here,
and we put trails on them, like this,Now, this is, more or less, if you look
at the average data of the countries --And even more, policy makers
and the corporate sectorsAll that information
we saw changing in the world(Laughter)And this won't work.(Applause)So what is needed? We have the databases.Some countries accept that
their databases can go out on the world.But this is what we would
like to see, isn't it?(Laughter)And that's a quite clever guy, huh?(Laughter)So we can see a lot happening
in data in the coming years.(Laughter)It's pretty scary.(Laughter)But I think it's very important
to have all this information.I end now with the world.Thank you very much.(Applause)
